tidygedcom 0.0.0.9000

Naming individuals

Source: vignettes/individual_names.Rmd
individual_names.Rmd

Introduction

Within a GEDCOM file, individuals can be given more than one name. These can be different kinds of name such as birth name or adoptive name, or if there is uncertainty, variants of these based on conflicting evidence sources. There is also the ability to provide phonetic and romanised variants of names. Given this complexity, the name is not immediately defined when creating an Individual record.

Adding individual names

The main function for providing names for an individual is add_individual_names():

library(tidygedcom)
#> If importing existing GEDCOM files, you should ensure that they are error free.
#> This package assumes imported GEDCOM files are valid and very few validation checks are carried out.
#> Several GEDCOM validators are available, including an online validator at http://ged-inline.elasticbeanstalk.com/

gedcom(subm("Me")) %>% 
  add_individual() %>% 
  add_individual_names("Leia /Skywalker/") %>% 
  dplyr::filter(record == "@I1@")
#> # A tibble: 6 x 4
#>   level record tag   value             
#>   <dbl> <chr>  <chr> <chr>             
#> 1     0 @I1@   INDI  ""                
#> 2     1 @I1@   SEX   "U"               
#> 3     1 @I1@   NAME  "Leia /Skywalker/"
#> 4     2 @I1@   SURN  "Skywalker"       
#> 5     1 @I1@   CHAN  ""                
#> 6     2 @I1@   DATE  "09 JAN 2021"

In the GEDCOM specification, all names should also be accompanied by a set of name pieces, specifying the given name, surname, nickname, etc. In addition, full names should always surround surnames with forward slashes. In tidygedcom this allows us to automatically generate a name piece if none are given. If we provide a name with no name pieces and no forward slashes, it will cause an error:

gedcom(subm("Me")) %>% 
  add_individual() %>% 
  add_individual_names("Leia Skywalker")
#> Error in salvage_name_pieces(name_personal, name_pieces): The name Leia Skywalker is given without any name pieces

Ideally, as much information as possible should be given:

gedcom(subm("Me")) %>% 
  add_individual() %>% 
  add_individual_names("Leia /Skywalker/", type = "birth", given = "Leia", surname = "Skywalker") %>% 
  dplyr::filter(record == "@I1@")
#> # A tibble: 8 x 4
#>   level record tag   value             
#>   <dbl> <chr>  <chr> <chr>             
#> 1     0 @I1@   INDI  ""                
#> 2     1 @I1@   SEX   "U"               
#> 3     1 @I1@   NAME  "Leia /Skywalker/"
#> 4     2 @I1@   TYPE  "birth"           
#> 5     2 @I1@   GIVN  "Leia"            
#> 6     2 @I1@   SURN  "Skywalker"       
#> 7     1 @I1@   CHAN  ""                
#> 8     2 @I1@   DATE  "09 JAN 2021"

Phonetic and romanised names

Once we have defined a name for an individual, we can also define phonetic and romanised versions of the name. For this, we use the add_individual_names_var() function. As a minimum, the original name, variant name, derivation method, and whether it is a phonetic or romanised variation should be given:

gedcom(subm("Me")) %>% 
  add_individual() %>% 
  add_individual_names("Leia /Skywalker/", type = "birth", given = "Leia", surname = "Skywalker") %>% 
  add_individual_names_var("Leia /Skywalker/", "Laya /Skywalker/", type = "As spoken",
                           phonetic_variation = TRUE) %>% 
  dplyr::filter(record == "@I1@")
#> # A tibble: 11 x 4
#>    level record tag   value             
#>    <dbl> <chr>  <chr> <chr>             
#>  1     0 @I1@   INDI  ""                
#>  2     1 @I1@   SEX   "U"               
#>  3     1 @I1@   NAME  "Leia /Skywalker/"
#>  4     2 @I1@   TYPE  "birth"           
#>  5     2 @I1@   GIVN  "Leia"            
#>  6     2 @I1@   SURN  "Skywalker"       
#>  7     2 @I1@   FONE  "Laya /Skywalker/"
#>  8     3 @I1@   TYPE  "As spoken"       
#>  9     3 @I1@   SURN  "Skywalker"       
#> 10     1 @I1@   CHAN  ""                
#> 11     2 @I1@   DATE  "09 JAN 2021"

As with the original name, if there are no name pieces or forward slashes, it will result in an error. Ideally we provide as much information as possible:

gedcom(subm("Me")) %>% 
  add_individual() %>% 
  add_individual_names("Leia /Skywalker/", type = "birth", given = "Leia", surname = "Skywalker") %>% 
  add_individual_names_var("Leia /Skywalker/", "Laya /Skywalker/", type = "As spoken", 
                           phonetic_variation = TRUE, given = "Laya", surname = "Skywalker") %>% 
  dplyr::filter(record == "@I1@")
#> # A tibble: 12 x 4
#>    level record tag   value             
#>    <dbl> <chr>  <chr> <chr>             
#>  1     0 @I1@   INDI  ""                
#>  2     1 @I1@   SEX   "U"               
#>  3     1 @I1@   NAME  "Leia /Skywalker/"
#>  4     2 @I1@   TYPE  "birth"           
#>  5     2 @I1@   GIVN  "Leia"            
#>  6     2 @I1@   SURN  "Skywalker"       
#>  7     2 @I1@   FONE  "Laya /Skywalker/"
#>  8     3 @I1@   TYPE  "As spoken"       
#>  9     3 @I1@   GIVN  "Laya"            
#> 10     3 @I1@   SURN  "Skywalker"       
#> 11     1 @I1@   CHAN  ""                
#> 12     2 @I1@   DATE  "09 JAN 2021"

Name types

All of the above define the variants for a single birth name. The type parameter can also define different names for the individual. Below we add a line to define an adoptive name:

gedcom(subm("Me")) %>% 
  add_individual() %>% 
  add_individual_names("Leia /Skywalker/", type = "birth", given = "Leia", surname = "Skywalker") %>% 
  add_individual_names_var("Leia /Skywalker/", "Laya /Skywalker/", type = "As spoken", 
                           phonetic_variation = TRUE, given = "Laya", surname = "Skywalker") %>% 
  add_individual_names("Leia /Organa/", type = "adoptive", given = "Leia", surname = "Organa") %>% 
  dplyr::filter(record == "@I1@") %>% print(n = Inf)
#> # A tibble: 16 x 4
#>    level record tag   value             
#>    <dbl> <chr>  <chr> <chr>             
#>  1     0 @I1@   INDI  ""                
#>  2     1 @I1@   SEX   "U"               
#>  3     1 @I1@   NAME  "Leia /Skywalker/"
#>  4     2 @I1@   TYPE  "birth"           
#>  5     2 @I1@   GIVN  "Leia"            
#>  6     2 @I1@   SURN  "Skywalker"       
#>  7     2 @I1@   FONE  "Laya /Skywalker/"
#>  8     3 @I1@   TYPE  "As spoken"       
#>  9     3 @I1@   GIVN  "Laya"            
#> 10     3 @I1@   SURN  "Skywalker"       
#> 11     1 @I1@   NAME  "Leia /Organa/"   
#> 12     2 @I1@   TYPE  "adoptive"        
#> 13     2 @I1@   GIVN  "Leia"            
#> 14     2 @I1@   SURN  "Organa"          
#> 15     1 @I1@   CHAN  ""                
#> 16     2 @I1@   DATE  "09 JAN 2021"

Conflicting names

GEDCOM files can also record different names of the same type, due to conflicting evidence. Below we define a name of Leia Skywaker (with no l) indicating some kind of transcription error:

gedcom(subm("Me")) %>% 
  add_individual() %>% 
  add_individual_names("Leia /Skywalker/", type = "birth", given = "Leia", surname = "Skywalker") %>% 
  add_individual_names_var("Leia /Skywalker/", "Laya /Skywalker/", type = "As spoken", 
                           phonetic_variation = TRUE, given = "Laya", surname = "Skywalker") %>% 
  add_individual_names("Leia /Organa/", type = "adoptive", given = "Leia", surname = "Organa") %>% 
  add_individual_names("Leia /Skywaker/", type = "birth", given = "Leia", surname = "Skywaker") %>%
  dplyr::filter(record == "@I1@") %>% print(n = Inf)
#> # A tibble: 20 x 4
#>    level record tag   value             
#>    <dbl> <chr>  <chr> <chr>             
#>  1     0 @I1@   INDI  ""                
#>  2     1 @I1@   SEX   "U"               
#>  3     1 @I1@   NAME  "Leia /Skywalker/"
#>  4     2 @I1@   TYPE  "birth"           
#>  5     2 @I1@   GIVN  "Leia"            
#>  6     2 @I1@   SURN  "Skywalker"       
#>  7     2 @I1@   FONE  "Laya /Skywalker/"
#>  8     3 @I1@   TYPE  "As spoken"       
#>  9     3 @I1@   GIVN  "Laya"            
#> 10     3 @I1@   SURN  "Skywalker"       
#> 11     1 @I1@   NAME  "Leia /Organa/"   
#> 12     2 @I1@   TYPE  "adoptive"        
#> 13     2 @I1@   GIVN  "Leia"            
#> 14     2 @I1@   SURN  "Organa"          
#> 15     1 @I1@   NAME  "Leia /Skywaker/" 
#> 16     2 @I1@   TYPE  "birth"           
#> 17     2 @I1@   GIVN  "Leia"            
#> 18     2 @I1@   SURN  "Skywaker"        
#> 19     1 @I1@   CHAN  ""                
#> 20     2 @I1@   DATE  "09 JAN 2021"

Generally conflicting names are arranged in order of confidence; the first name is more likely to be correct. If you want to promote a name to occur first in the record, you can use the primary_individual_name() function:

gedcom(subm("Me")) %>% 
  add_individual() %>% 
  add_individual_names("Leia /Skywalker/", type = "birth", given = "Leia", surname = "Skywalker") %>% 
  add_individual_names_var("Leia /Skywalker/", "Laya /Skywalker/", type = "As spoken", 
                           phonetic_variation = TRUE, given = "Laya", surname = "Skywalker") %>% 
  add_individual_names("Leia /Organa/", type = "adoptive", given = "Leia", surname = "Organa") %>% 
  add_individual_names("Leia /Skywaker/", type = "birth", given = "Leia", surname = "Skywaker") %>%
  primary_individual_name("Leia /Skywaker/") %>% 
  dplyr::filter(record == "@I1@") %>% print(n = Inf)
#> # A tibble: 20 x 4
#>    level record tag   value             
#>    <dbl> <chr>  <chr> <chr>             
#>  1     0 @I1@   INDI  ""                
#>  2     1 @I1@   NAME  "Leia /Skywaker/" 
#>  3     2 @I1@   TYPE  "birth"           
#>  4     2 @I1@   GIVN  "Leia"            
#>  5     2 @I1@   SURN  "Skywaker"        
#>  6     1 @I1@   SEX   "U"               
#>  7     1 @I1@   NAME  "Leia /Skywalker/"
#>  8     2 @I1@   TYPE  "birth"           
#>  9     2 @I1@   GIVN  "Leia"            
#> 10     2 @I1@   SURN  "Skywalker"       
#> 11     2 @I1@   FONE  "Laya /Skywalker/"
#> 12     3 @I1@   TYPE  "As spoken"       
#> 13     3 @I1@   GIVN  "Laya"            
#> 14     3 @I1@   SURN  "Skywalker"       
#> 15     1 @I1@   NAME  "Leia /Organa/"   
#> 16     2 @I1@   TYPE  "adoptive"        
#> 17     2 @I1@   GIVN  "Leia"            
#> 18     2 @I1@   SURN  "Organa"          
#> 19     1 @I1@   CHAN  ""                
#> 20     2 @I1@   DATE  "09 JAN 2021"

Note that the subrecords of the Individual record (those at level 1) can appear in any order.
